facts.text: The land in suit, area a little over 9 acres (9 acres 49 cents of wet land), was property of Basappa who died before 1918 leaving three daughters: Paramma, Pompamma and Hampamma.
Under settlement with Basappa's reversioner, evidenced by registered deeds Exhibits P-2 (1918) and P-3 (1919), three sisters got 15-16 acres wet land in absolute right.
Hampamma took her one-third share; remaining two-thirds share (9 acres 49 cents) enjoyed by Paramma and Pompamma, subject-matter of suit.
Pompamma married Nagana Gowd, gave birth to two sons Siddalingana and Chenabasavana, died in 1923; her share devolved upon the two sons.
After Pompamma's death, Nagana remarried and stayed in ancestral village; two infant sons remained at village Kampli with Paramma, who reared them.
On 22nd June 1923, Paramma executed deed of gift conveying her share in suit property to two sons of Pompamma; entirety of 9 acres 49 cents owned jointly by two sons.
Siddalingana (elder son) died in 1924; plaintiff's case: his half-share devolved on father Nagana under Hindu law of inheritance.
Paramma continued to possess entirety of land on behalf of younger son Chenabasavana (defendant No. 1).
On 25th August 1926, lease deed Exhibit D-1 and counterpart D-2: Nagana as father/guardian of infant Chenabasavana granted lease of entire property to Paramma for 12 years at Rs. 500/year.
Rent receipts Exhibits D-4 (1927) and D-4-1 (1932) passed by Nagana to Paramma on behalf of Chenabasavana.

In 1934, Nagana as guardian of Chenabasavana sued Paramma in Munsif's Court Hospet for Rs. 500 rent; decreed ex parte, discharged by Exhibit D-3 (14th November 1934) reciting rents paid as Paramma borrowed for minor.

Nagana became financially involved; on 27th August 1935, executed mortgage by conditional sale of half-share of disputed land to defendant No. 2 for Rs. 3,000; recited half-share devolved on death of Siddalingana, mortgagor in possession.
On 16th July 1936, Nagana sold mortgaged property (half-share) to defendant No. 2 by deed Exhibit P-6 for Rs. 3,000.
Defendant No. 2 never obtained possession.
On 2nd May 1944, defendant No. 2 sold property to plaintiff by conveyance Exhibit P-1.
On 18th July 1944, plaintiff filed Original Suit No. 17 of 1944 in District Judge Bellary against Chenabasavana (defendant No. 1) for half-share after partition, defendant No. 2 impleaded.

Trial Judge (District Judge Bellary) dismissed suit on 23rd July 1945: deed of gift conferred no right on Nagana, disclaimed by lease/receipts; plaintiff never in possession within 12 years; Nagana disclaimed as co-owner.

Plaintiff appealed to High Court Madras (Appeal No. 654 of 1945); Division Bench (Rajamannar C.J., Balakrishna Ayyar J.) allowed appeal on 28th March 1949: sons tenants-in-common, Nagana got interest; no adverse possession as animus ceased in 1935.
Defendant No. 1 appealed to Supreme Court on certificate under Article 133 Constitution read with Sections 109, 110 CPC.
Defendant No. 1's defences: (1) donees joint tenants with survivorship, Siddalingana's interest to defendant No. 1; (2) plaintiff barred by adverse possession.

legal_issues.text: Whether the two sons took property under deed of gift as joint tenants (survivorship to surviving brother) or tenants-in-common (interest of deceased son to father Nagana).
Whether defendant No. 1 acquired title to half-share by adverse possession against Nagana and his alienees, given acts like lease by Nagana as guardian and later mortgage.

petitioner_arguments.text: Nagana disclaimed rights as co-owner by lease deed (1926), receipts, rent suit (1934); acted only as guardian of Chenabasavana; presumption of one co-owner's possession for all does not apply; adverse possession from 1926.
Not pressing joint tenancy point in Supreme Court; accepts Nagana became co-owner after Siddalingana's death.

respondent_arguments.text: Sons took as tenants-in-common; Siddalingana's interest vested in father Nagana.
Nagana's animus to hold solely for Chenabasavana lasted only till 1935 mortgage asserting own half-share right; adverse possession interrupted.

court_reasoning.text: Accepts no joint tenancy argument pressed; Nagana co-owner with infant son Chenabasavana; presumption possession of one co-owner for other unless ouster proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant must prove adverse possession for statutory period.

court_reasoning.text: Nagana's lease (1926) as guardian asserted son's exclusive title, denying own; lessee's possession is lessor's (son's); adverse even with father's consent/knowledge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adverse possession possible with consent of true owner.

court_reasoning.text: 1935 mortgage mere assertion of title by dispossessed father; does not interrupt adverse possession without re-entry, resumption of possession, or acknowledgment by possessor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No change in possession; property leased to Paramma; Nagana continued acknowledging son's title via receipts, suit.

court_reasoning.text: Father's acts re lease as guardian are son's acts; mortgage personal act of father qua proprietor, adverse to son; no effect on continuity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guardian cannot unilaterally change for minor.

court_reasoning.text: Defendant No. 1 in possession throughout; no act acknowledging father's title.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adverse possession completes; plaintiff suit barred.

holdings.text: After Siddalingana's death, Nagana co-owner but dispossessed adversely by son from 1926 via lease etc.; 1935 mortgage did not interrupt.
Defendant No. 1 acquired title by adverse possession; plaintiff not entitled.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of High Court set aside; judgment and decree of District Judge restored; plaintiff's suit dismissed.

key_quotes.text: In law the possession of the lessee is the possession of the lessor and consequently ever since 1926 when Paramma began to possess the property as a lessee in terms of the lease deed, her possession in law was the possession of the infant alone to the exclusion of Nagana, the father.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains start of adverse possession via lease.

key_quotes.text: There can be in law, under certain circumstances, adverse possession with the consent of the true owner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle applied to father's consent.

key_quotes.text: Once it is held that the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession.
key_quotes.speaker: court
